thread.title: Full ‘STEAM’ ahead: New tech lab opens for Muscogee County students
thread.title_full: Full ‘STEAM’ ahead: New tech lab opens for Muscogee County students

author: Olivia Yepez
title: Full ‘STEAM’ ahead: New tech lab opens for Muscogee County students
text:
WRBL Columbus Full ‘STEAM’ ahead: New tech lab opens for Muscogee County students Olivia Yepez Thu, December 5, 2024 at 11:11 PM UTC 2 min read
COLUMBUS, Ga. ( WRBL ) — The future is STEAM. At least according to local nonprofit Let’s Grow STEAM X which opened a new learning lab for Muscogee County students the morning of Dec. 5.
“Science, engineering, technology is what—where—the world is going,” Robbie Branscomb, CEO and founder of Let’s Grow STEAM X , said.
She added it’s important to give local students exposure to the tools and technology used in STEAM (science, technology, engineering, arts and mathematics).
Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement ‘The Nutcracker’: Professional dancers join Columbus Ballet for performance
“Ensuring that they are prepared, ensuring that they have a good understanding of what’s required of them so they can be successful,” Branscomb said, “I think we just don’t have enough resources like that in the community.”
J.D. Davis Elementary students became the first local children to check out the lab, following a ribbon cutting ceremony this morning. It will allow students to explore science, technology, engineering, arts and mathematics in a hands-on environment.
J.D. Davis Elementary students became the first local children to check out the lab, following a ribbon cutting ceremony. (Olivia Yepez) The future is STEAM. At least according to local nonprofit Let’s Grow STEAMX which opened a new learning lab for Muscogee County students the morning of Dec. 5. (Olivia Yepez) Let’s Grow STEAMX plans to partner with local companies and organizations to inspire students to chase careers in STEAM. (Olivia Yepez) Let’s Grow STEAMX is preparing to begin its annual gravity racing season, which will allow students to design, engineer and race their own soap box cars. (Olivia Yepez) The building, which has been under construction for three months, was funded through grants, sponsorships and community support. It was opened in partnership with Amdocs and the Black Professionals Employee Networking Group (BPENG).
Advertisement Advertisement It features a tech lab, as well as multiple classrooms for hands-on learning.
Let’s Grow STEAM X plans to partner with local companies and organizations to inspire students to chase careers in STEAM.
BizPitch: Auburn junior proposes hot take on coffee, UGA grad uses sound to clean pools
BPENG President Curtina Brewton, who works with Amdocs, is hopeful for the impact the new lab will have on the community. She envisions Muscogee County students becoming future AI consultants, computer experts and more.
Brewton said, “If I can get ten out of the 30 to go and build [a] future for the next, our job is done.”

Mystery player was part of an incredibly rare draw LA Times 2 kindergarteners in 'critical but stable condition' after Christian school shooting ABC News Let’s Grow STEAM X has been working to bring more educational opportunities to Muscogee County students for the past eight years. It is preparing to begin its annual gravity racing season, which will allow students to design, engineer and race their own soap box cars.
You can find more information about the new lab and the gravity racing season by visiting the Let’s Grow STEAM X website .
